Iâ€™m glad you have the self insight to understand your validity as a woman and your struggles not being evidence of being trans. This is what matters most. But you are correct that therapists think diagnosing someone as trans or allowing them to transition is easier and simpler than tackling multiple chronic mental health issues. If I were you, Iâ€™d calmly but assertively say that youâ€™re sex is not negotiable just because you have self hate issues. Iâ€™d try to educate her on some gender critical concepts such as people having gender/sex/body dysphoria, but not needing to pretend to be the opposite sex in order to cope. Tbh Iâ€™d be pissed that these issues prompt asking the trans question, and have a lengthy discussion about it with any person. Because if she is bringing it up to you, you know she is doing it with other clients too. Other vulnerable mentally ill people who might not have the understanding and grip on reality that you do. Itâ€™s worth it to try and give her the GC view

I always say that I am the best lover Iâ€™ve ever had. I know all my spots. I can get myself off every time. 

But joking aside, I really am just looking for someone who is very much like me. Itâ€™s not that I think Iâ€™m a great person, I have plenty of things to work on, but in most respects I kinda just wanna date myself but as a male. I know thatâ€™s not possible. 

So I basically just look for myself except maybe some people are even better or where I am aiming for, so Iâ€™m into those people too. I realize however that from their point of view, I am similar but less than them in those ways they are better, so I can understand why they might reject me.

Rejecting men who are Crossing your boundaries isnâ€™t picky too picky; itâ€™s safe. If a man is doing something you feel crosses your boundaries in a large enough way, itâ€™s a sign he will just get worse. Iâ€™m in the same position. I am very picky and dismissive. I have little tolerance. In the past I was far too forgiving because I had lower self esteem and wouldnâ€™t want to be judged harshly myself, but now I see that itâ€™s not my problem if men are fucked up in some way. Let their therapists or friends support them in their efforts to improve. You shouldnâ€™t use a dating partner especially a new dating partner as a dump for your problems and lack of self esteem. That goes for women too. I work on my own self esteem and issues and do not rely on others, including men, and they work on their issues and do not rely on others, women. 

That results in there being almost no men in my area who have any chance at my interest. When others say you are being too picky, itâ€™s probably because they themselves settled. Due to the high volumes of shitty men, and decent men with shitty behavior, that leaves women forced to be alone, or to settle, or to keep searching. And most choose to settle. It is appealing of course, but after dating some true low lifeâ€™s, Iâ€™m not about to settle for anything less than someone who fully matches my good energies, beliefs, and respect.

Yeah men arenâ€™t reading the profiles. I had a male to female trans friend get a million messages on okcupid under the guise of being female. It said he was trans mtf right at the top. He politely stated he was trans lower down in the description. But he kept getting messages from straight dudes who obviously didnâ€™t read the profile. They went on photos alone or skimmed it. When he stated very blatantly that he was trans right at the beginning all his messages dropped off. Itâ€™s clear before that the men werenâ€™t actually reading or paying attention to the profile. 

And of course if you look at the quality of men who are thirsting like that itâ€™s just as bad or worse physically mentally and socially than the fake profile. Creeps will thirst after anyone. Itâ€™s not a compliment for some low lifeâ€™s and awkward creepy dudes to hit up your profile online.

Iâ€™ve been making art about the virus, collages and digital paintings. While itâ€™s tempting to go into stores and stuff and snap some pics of the empty shelves, Iâ€™m pretty much not going out if I can anywhere. I have gone out with the camera on walks with a good distance away from everyone but people seemed more or less acting the same. I saw one person with a mask on but there were a lot of people in groups or even with their babies. There really wasnâ€™t much to document because people seem to be ignoring a lot of the stay at home warnings. In my state you can go out for walks as long as you keep your distance, but thatâ€™s it. 
So Iâ€™d say try thinking of other creative ways to document it besides capturing it literally in photographs. You could set up a photo shoot in your house with items about the virus and make it more conceptual than photo journalistic

Being autistic and perpetually gnc plus very sexual and other â€œmasculineâ€ type things made me not relate to being a woman at all. Rejecting femininity in every way and feeling alien in this world made me think it would be easier to be a male. Add on severe depression, ptsd, a d being suicidal and I had an identity crisis. Add on to that being led on by multiple gay men and falling in love with them and hating myself for not being attractive to them and thatâ€™s how I ended up being trans. I ended up detransitioning four years later when I realized that even after top surgery and hormones that I felt no better about myself, that I was actually getting worse, and that I didnâ€™t need to pretend to be a man in order to be myself. I realized very clearly how my trauma and self hate causes me to desire an escape and a molding into a new person who I thought would be a better version of me, instead, i was actually a worse version, hating my body and sex, resenting my sexuality and reality. Realized it was a big charade and that I could be valid as a gnc woman, I just needed to practice some radical self love and acceptance. I used to cry about hating my genitals and stuff Now I am so happy just being a woman because I realize that my body is there for me, itâ€™s healthy and normal. And I was never really supposed to be a man, or be trans, I just thought transition could help my depression and self hate. Instead, actual therapy, mindfulness, and self love have helped my depression and self esteem. I no longer am jealous of men or want to be a gay man because I realized that I am my body, I am my sex, I am my genitalia, and I wouldnâ€™t be me without those things, and trying to be something else was unnatural and irrational. People think Iâ€™m a guy sometimes but I donâ€™t care if they think Iâ€™m a man or a woman because Iâ€™m secure with my sex now, unlike in the past when I was extremely insecure and constantly worried about being masculine enough or passing or whatever. 
Short answer: I was trans because of mental illness trauma and identity confusion due to being autistic and a weird girl. And I stopped being trans because I put in the work in therapy and accepted myself for what I am; a weird mentally ill girl.

It does feel very frustrating at times. Nobody bothers to actually read up and investigate the matters, so no one knows what theyâ€™re on about. Theyâ€™re not thinking critically. But I assure you that there are tons of lgb, especially lesbians who fully agree with you. There are many Facebook groups, people on twitter, tumblr, etc. little groups of mutuals who keep each other sane. Itâ€™s harder in real life circles. I donâ€™t keep my views hidden from anybody. The truth is that the reason people get angry with gender critical views is that they are scared that they are invalidated some how. They are insecure. Itâ€™s not your fault that they arenâ€™t in a good place to think critically about it. Lots of people lose friends over that stuff. Itâ€™s probably best not to provoke your friends. But you can state your views in language that is less offensive to them, more neutral and rational. If you did bring it up, have a mature and genuine discussion. Donâ€™t even bring up the term radical feminism. Most people agree with radfem beliefs to some extent but they get turned off at the associations with it. To say that you should be allowed to choose your sexual partners as a freedom of sexual choice, vs that you donâ€™t think trans women are women is an example of how to remain more neutral. Of course, a lot of times the beliefs grow and you might get passionate about them. In general I will speak my mind and anyone in my life knows that. If they actually care about you they will respect your beliefs but you also must be open to their beliefs too. Tolerating them. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s good to keep major secrets but itâ€™s true that itâ€™s a huge risk to fully state your beliefs. A lot of people get dumped by their friends. Itâ€™s due to their personal insecurities. ğŸ¤· the thing is that I have my own demons. Iâ€™m not going to placate anybody elseâ€™s in spite of mine. I do find that friends tend to be more rational and nuanced than random people online so if you do mention anything just be personal about it aka donâ€™t state rhetoric just state how it effects you personally and they hopefully would understand enough just as you understand their position enough. That is if you ever want to talk to them honestly about it.

Non-binary doesnâ€™t actually mean anything concrete. Itâ€™s basically an abstract way to say that you donâ€™t like gender norms and are probably quirky. Therefore non binary people donâ€™t face any discrimination except for well deserved joking about it online on occasion. However, there are some people who transition who ID as non-binary. So those people could potentially have some issues. They could have some mental health issues with gender dysphoria, but unless they actually transition they face no discrimination. Unless the â€œdiscriminationâ€ they mean is having to acknowledge that theyâ€™re either male or female on a legal form or some bullshit. Most of the time the â€œdiscriminationâ€ is just society being rational and not indulging their abstract feeling of the social construct of gender, or people refusing to use they/them pronouns, which isnâ€™t discrimination, itâ€™s (using he or she) is just social shorthand for describing men and women. I think non-binary identity is a joke. I understand the urge to try and get away from restrictive gender constructs, but pretending you are â€œsomething elseâ€ besides male or female either â€œinternallyâ€ or physically is absurd. Just be a non conforming male or female. Thatâ€™s far more radical than pretending you donâ€™t have a sex or that you are somehow enlightened by living â€œbeyondâ€ gender with meaningless abstract gender labels suited to fit every individual and which thus mean nothing outside of a cute nickname type of thing. â€œGenderstarâ€ etc etc

Iâ€™d say for most including me it was worth it to have them. They brought so much joy for their short lives. But most people end up getting hooked on their two rats and then just buying more and more when the others die

It usually depends on the crowd at the show how it will be. For example I see a lot of older bands and the crowd is old and they like to just sit and watch. But a young artist will have a young crowd that might get wild. There will probably be drinking and drugs around you so if you donâ€™t want that try and sit away from the rowdy people. There will be plenty of people dancing and standing up and singing along. Donâ€™t be afraid to let your body move if you want it to. I get self aware of my bad dancing or whatever but it really doesnâ€™t even matter to anyone else so long as you arenâ€™t bumping Into them. Just stay out of the front if you donâ€™t want to be in a crowd of sweaty drunk people dancing. Also there will be a lot of lights colors smoke and visual stimulation so idk if you might want to close your eyes for some parts of it gets to be too much. And of course it will be very loud the whole time so bring something to muffle the noise if youâ€™re worried about that. I am not bothered by any of those things so I usually just have a few beers smoke some weed and sing along and have a good time. Also bring some water or buy it because you might get hot

Yeah I donâ€™t know how I feel about my own top surgery. Well, I do know, I hate it and regret it, but I mean the surgeon himself. He was a plastic surgeon who practiced trans stuff too. He was a very nice and caring guy, he did seem genuinely concerned about my mental health. But at the same time, it was quite irresponsible to perform that surgery on a healthy body. But the thing is that he did require two letters of recommendation  from doctors first, so he was trying to follow the accepted guidelines for trans patients. I feel like I canâ€™t really blame the guy for trying to make money. Iâ€™d probably do the same if I thought I was following the proper guidelines. I feel much more angry at the many therapists who were unhelpful, the general practitioner who wrote one letter of recommendation who barely even knew me, and my psychiatrist who knew I was fucked up and suicidal and had all these issues and still deemed me stable enough to make a surgical decision like that. I feel like none of these doctors know whatâ€™s really going on and theyâ€™re all just listening to the transpoganda forcing everyone to just blindly validate it. Idk. Sometimes I think about contacting the surgeons office maybe anonymously and writing all this but Iâ€™m scared of being dismissed. And the general doctor too, I still see her. I feel I should say something. My former psychiatrist died so I canâ€™t tell her but so far I just donâ€™t feel comfortable doing it, or I havenâ€™t had the opportunity to bring attention to it. If they asked a survey or something online that didnâ€™t require direct contact id probably talk about detransition but so far itâ€™s a little much for me.

I donâ€™t really approve of cosmetic surgery but I also think that itâ€™s a persons right to have it if itâ€™s safe to do. Unfortunately, they arenâ€™t calling trans surgery what it really is-cosmetic surgery. Theyâ€™re calling it â€œhealth careâ€ getting it covered by insurance, and itâ€™s ridiculous. My opinion is, itâ€™s your body, if youâ€™re an adult go fuck with it how you want, but donâ€™t pretend itâ€™s health care, and dont make taxpayers contribute to it. And especially do not allow children to have it done.

You know, I know a TIM who is a gay man but also is AGP too. I donâ€™t really understand it. I for one though, do not support transition for any reason unless itâ€™s for physical safety (example, a woman pretending to be a man in order to escape male predators). I think that regardless of the misogyny or sexism inherent in transition, itâ€™s really just a pretty mentally unhealthy thing to do for anybody. To deny ones body is to deny both reality and ones self. You canâ€™t separate the body and mind since the brain is part of the body. Thus, to pretend to be the opposite sex is to deny yourself, and reality. Denying reality is never a healthy thing to do. Itâ€™s irrational or straight up delusional. From a mental health perspective, itâ€™s damaging to pretend to be something you arenâ€™t, hate yourself own body, and surgically change it, or even desire to change it. So no, I donâ€™t approve of TIMS (or TIFS) transitioning even for non fetish  reasons.

So you donâ€™t know what could have triggered this doubt? An event, a post online or anything? My advice is to write down your exact mindset and thought process. Record stream of consciousness journal type writings to delve into your thoughts and feelings, try to discover why thereâ€™s a part of you saying watch out, how theyâ€™re saying it, when and why theyâ€™re saying it. Possibly look up videos of people with doubts on YouTube and see if you relate or disagree with what they say. Sometimes the doubt will be relieved once you explore it and acknowledge it and where it comes from, sometimes it will grow larger and more fine tuned once you explore it. But yeah if you donâ€™t acknowledge it and be real about it then it will make you increasingly anxious stressed and could creep up on you later and be much more severe

And Donâ€™t give in to the pressure to pick a major from your parents, they probably just want to make sure you arenâ€™t going to waste their money and that you arenâ€™t going to just fuck around and blow off school. At worst, you can also tell them a tentative major to appease them even if you arenâ€™t officially declaring it. Good luck to you!

Well, most people feel the same way, I know I did at that age. I was so suicidal for years I never thought about the future. Most people donâ€™t know what they really want to do. If they say they do they are likely to change their mind later on. So donâ€™t feel weird about that. 

The first thing to do is to A LOT of self reflection. What clubs or activities did you do in your school years? As a kid? What are your hobbies or interests? What do you hate doing? What are your best subjects and worst subjects? You can cross out options easier than not to eliminate things. I eliminated math science and physical labor straight away and knew I wanted to avoid those. 

Next, take a variety of career and personality tests. The big five, enneagram, Myers Briggs, etc etc etc. Not only are they fun, but they can tell you things about yourself. If you consistently get labeled with a certain type of intelligence, be aware of that. Career inventories are cool because they will take your personality traits and interests and recommend specific fields jobs and majors based on them. More sophisticated tests will tell you specifics of those jobs, their requirements, the schooling needed, and average salaries. You can find a variety of these tests online, or maybe your school offers some too. Explore those. 

Then, try to eliminate different types of colleges. Theirs a regular university with liberal arts in which you will be required to take a breadth of courses in different areas. Those can be useful for when you want to try different things and see if you like them or not. Then thereâ€™s specific colleges for the arts or theater. Obviously those will be focused more on varying types of creativity and artistry and less on traditional liberal arts courses. Or maybe a trade school? Where they are less focused on arts or an overview of many traditional courses and focus on a very specific skill or labor. Usually those require fewer years in school to complete. Try to narrow it down to one of those types of colleges and you can then explore the programs of that type at various ones. 

Finally, keep these things in mind. The job you have now or get during school wonâ€™t be your job forever. Donâ€™t feel pressured to stick with something you donâ€™t care about just because you have experience or are familiar with it. Go in with an open mind and explore different areas to learn more while completing your requirements. Donâ€™t declare any major right away even though you will be pressured to. Remain undecided for a year or two if need be. Most people change their major anyway once or twice. Also, try to network while you do it by getting friendly with various students clubs teachers internships etc so you have more opportunities in the future once you do graduate doing whatever. 

I wish I had done all these things at your age. But I was too depressed to care so I ended up going to the main liberal arts college by my home with no plans at all. After four years of being undecided and unhappy I finally realized I should have gone to art school right away, and I joined the art program at my college last semester. Iâ€™m going to be a few years late graduating but itâ€™s well worth it to pursue my passions for a long term career in what I truly care about.

Also, itâ€™s very hard to avoid the capitalist struggle of work. Just try to play the system when you can and maybe find an easy part time job on campus while youâ€™re in school to get experience and make a little money. If you find the right career suited for your abilities, personality, education level, interests, and general needs, then it makes working for most of your life at least sometimes rewarding. Donâ€™t forget to network and not burn bridges if you can too so that when you graduate with a degree you arenâ€™t totally lost at what to do with it or where to work.

Hiding pain is no help. Itâ€™s only convenient to employers to let their employees hide their pain so they donâ€™t have to deal with it or acknowledge it. If I were you Iâ€™d have half a mind to stick up a piece of paper next to it with something like â€œhiding pain is unhealthy, etcâ€ cause that is bullshit

Itâ€™s been extremely refreshing to find the radfem community and the detrans community especially because many of them are also autistic and non conforming. But the best thing for me was finding a straight aligned radfem discord because sometimes itâ€™s a little alienating online within the mostly lesbian radfems. So Iâ€™ve found my niche and itâ€™s really awesome to be able to talk to women who understand radfem issues but who also understand attraction to men and how to cope with that.

Yes I agree with you. Young children are being told online or even in sex education classes that being a woman or man is a feeling or based in outdated stereotypes. Itâ€™s disgusting. And young children are being confused greatly about themselves. Even older children are being confused. The younger kids have no reason to not believe what the adults say and they donâ€™t have much of a grasp on what biology is or what gender is or what gender norms are so it makes sense that more kids are thinking theyâ€™re trans based on their abstract feelings about gender stuff. And the older kids teens and young adults are being told by propaganda constantly that gender identity is valid and that there are a million genders and that being trans is this totally normal healthy thing that is the path to being their true selves so of course theyâ€™re going to be likely to identify that way.
